Advances of entropy-stabilized homologous compounds for electrochemical energy storage Xin Wang 1 Xiang Li 1 Huarong Fan Ming Miao Yiming Zhang Wei Guo Yongzhu Fu ⁎ College of Chemistry, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, Henan, China College of Chemistry Zhengzhou University Zhengzhou 450001 Henan China College of Chemistry, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, Henan, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphic abstract High-entropy materials (HEMs) based on the entropy-stabilized concept have emerged out in electrochemical energy storage. The dazzling HEMs family is subjected to pursue superior performance with the novel structure-activity relationship. Recently, high-entropy materials (HEMs) have gained increasing interest in the field of energy storage technology on account of their unique structural characteristics and possibilities for tailoring functional properties. Herein, the development of this class of materials for electrochemical energy storage have been reviewed, especially the fundamental understanding of entropy-dominated phase-stabilization effects and prospective applications are presented. Subsequently, critical comments of HEMs on the different aspects of battery and supercapacitor are summarized with the underlying principles for the observed properties. In addition, we also summarize their potential advantages and remaining challenges, which will ideally provide some general guidelines and principles for researchers to study and develop advanced HEMs. The diversity of material design contributed by the entropy-mediated concept provides the researchers numerous ideas of new candidates for practical applications and ensures further research in the emerging field of energy storage. Keywords High entropy material Battery Supercapacitor Entropy-stabilized conversion mechanism 1 Introduction The explosive energy demand in the future would reach 28 TW by the year 2050 and most of the value is given rise due to the massive consumption of fossil fuels [1,2]. More importantly, the concentration increase of greenhouse gases due to the combustion of fossil fuels has resulted in severe environmental issues, such as global warming and ocean acidification. Although the widely used renewable energies can alleviate the energy shortage to a certain extent, the volatile energy supply will inevitably hinder their practical application. Therefore, more efficient energy storage systems are essential in the near future, which largely depends on the development of functional materials [3–5]. Recently, high-entropy materials (HEMs) based on the entropy-stabilization strategy have received increasing attention towards advanced functional applications. The library of HEMs includes alloys [6,7], oxides [8–13], oxyfluorides [14,15], borides [16], carbides [17–19], nitrides [20], sulfides [21], and phosphides [22], which prefer for single-phase solid solutions. By means of tailoring their constituent elements, HEMs give rise to attractive features and the functional properties, such as environmental protections [23], hydrogen storage [24,25], energy storage [26,27], thermoelectricity applications[28], and catalytic processes [29–31]. HEMs, as a novel family of energy storage materials, show infinite potential on account of the severe lattice distortion (strain) promoted by large entropy. For example, rock-salt type high-entropy oxides (HEOs) can be utilized as lithium storage anodes with enhanced cycling performance and higher efficiency than those of traditional oxides [9,14,15]. Moreover, layered structure of HEOs were studied as high-performance cathodes towards sodium/lithium storage owing to the entropy stabilization effect [10,32,33]. In addition, HEMs also manifest excellent performance in supercapacitors, which have large capacity and wide potential. Consequently, high entropy compounds can lead a new development direction in the electrochemical energy storage, and exploring the mechanism can further expand their application. Although there are several reviews related to the functional applications of HEMs, the recent work in the field of energy storage has not been summarized comprehensively. Meanwhile, the effects of entropy-stabilization strategy on the certain performance also are not outlined explicitly. In this review, we summarize an intensive overview of HEMs in rechargeable batteries and supercapacitors (Fig. 1 ). Finally, we systematically extract the potential advantages and challenges of the development of HEMs, accompanied by designing new materials of the high-entropy family, which will inspire scientists to develop advanced HEMs for energy storage. 2 Fundamental context of entropy-stabilized compounds The generalized high-entropy concept was first put forward in the aspects of alloys by two independent studies of Yeh [34] and Cantor [35] in 2004. From then on, high-entropy alloys (HEAs) have made considerable headway and revealed the breakthrough application in the field of technology. After the efforts of scientists in this period, a consensus towards the definition of HEAs was finally reached [36]. As for the composition definition, HEAs is the kind of alloys containing at least five metal elements and the atomic percentage of each element is between 5% and 35% [34]. For another definition, they are defined based on configurational entropy, which is larger than 1.5R at room temperature totally, regardless of their phase number [37]. According to the value of configurational entropy (1.5R and 1.0R), different materials can be classified as high-entropy, medium-entropy, and low-entropy class [38], as illustrated in Fig. 2 (a). Different from the traditional material system, multicomponent alloy materials have many special properties due to the introduction of the concept of high entropy. Among them, the four core effects [39] of HEAs are high-entropy effects, lattice distortions, sluggish diffusion, and cocktail effects, which endow them with various properties. The existence of severe lattice distortions caused by the different sizes of atoms introduces the surprising mechanical, electrical, thermal, optical, and chemical behavior (Fig. 2(b)) [6]. Furthermore, sluggish diffusion effect is associated with the nanocrystalline structures, and refers to slow kinetics of specific atoms during the phase transformation (Fig. 2(c)) [40,41]. Different from the “sluggish diffusion” concept in the field of batteries, which describes the slow ionic conduction, the influence of sluggish diffusion effect for HEA is waiting to be explored in future. Therefore, HEAs as atomic scale composites are equipped with superior properties due to cocktail effect incorporated by multi-principal metals [7]. The entropy-stabilized concept was first introduced to a multicomponent oxide in 2015, which Rost et al. [8] synthesized a single-phase (Mg0.2Co0.2Ni0.2Zn0.2Cu0.2)O with a rock salt structure stabilized by the configurational entropy, and accelerated the development of high entropy ceramics (HECs) [42,43]. With regard to the configurational entropy of high entropy materials, it can be calculated based on the following equation [9]: S c o n f i g = - R ∑ i = 1 N x i ln x ication - site + ∑ j = 1 M x j ln x janion - site where x i and x j represent the mole fraction of elements in the cation and anion sites, respectively. In order to achieve “entropy-stabilized”, the system must have both high configurational entropy and positive forming heat, thus being the entropy that controls its thermodynamic stability. Additionally, the reversibility between low-temperature multiphase and high-temperature single phase is a mandatory requirement of entropy-driven stabilization. It should be noted that the terms HEOs and entropy-stabilized oxides (ESOs) are different concepts [44]. The former strictly refers to multicomponent systems with high configurational entropy, while the latter refers correctly to Rost’s definition of “entropy-stabilization”. However, the theoretical concept of ESOs can be extended to rare earth and transition metal oxides, thus an understanding of the full potential of entropy-stabilized concept is still far from being unlocked. The structure and composition of HECs are various, as shown in Fig. 2(d). Among high entropy materials, the most developed HECs are rock-salt type, which are used in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) [9,45,46]. Especially, rock-salt type HECs show the possibility of cathode materials by introducing different metal cations and anions [15,47]. The perovskite structured HECs are also versatile via suitably being substituted by multiple metals [48–53]. Besides, other structures (such as fluorite [54–56], spinel [13,57,58], and layered oxides [10,32]) also unfold their potential in energy storage. Since the entropy stabilization concept has been applied in the field of energy storage for many years with a series of related work, thus it is necessary to summarize this field. This review will mainly focus on the development and prospect of entropy stabilization effect towards electrochemical energy storage. 3 Application of HEMs in rechargeable batteries It is well known that the normal HEOs are widely applied in the fields of catalyst [29,30] which include structure types of rock-salt (AO), spinel (AB2O4), perovskite (ABO3), and fluorite (AO2) (here A and B equal alkali or transition metals (TMs)). Recently, there are increasing researches focusing on HEOs for application in alkali-ion batteries (most of which are AO and AB2O4 type especially for Li-ion batteries) as anodes and cathodes [11,60]. Compared with other traditional electrodes, HEOs have more stable structure during charge and discharge processes. Moreover, the mechanism can be modified thanks to the high entropic stabilization. Here for this section, we summarize the commonly used HEM electrodes for the energy storage in batteries, including their progress, mechanism, and characteristics. 3.1 HEMs as anodes HEOs emerge into sight and embrace the blossom in very recent years, when Rost et al. successfully synthesized single phase (Co0.2Cu0.2Mg0.2Ni0.2Zn0.2)O (hereafter as (Co,Cu,Mg,Ni,Zn)O) in 2015 (homogeneous elements distribution are shown in Fig. 3 (a)) [8]. Thereafter, many researches focused on this typical HEO for its physical and chemical properties and further extended the family of HEOs. As one special class transition metal oxide (TMO), it is rational to design the HEOs as battery anodes, similar to the traditional TMOs based on conversion and/or alloy mechanism [61]. In this part, we review the HEOs which have been used or have potential as anodes for batteries, according to the structure type. 3.1.1 AO type The rock-salt AO type oxides are predominant of the HEO family, denoted as HERO. Specially, (Co,Cu,Mg,Ni,Zn)O is the central research subject for the researchers. It is important to note that MgO, NiO, and CoO are of rock-salt structure, while CuO and ZnO belong to tenorite and wurtzite, respectively. For non-rock-salt structural oxides, there must be phase transition, which requires more energy to overcome the enthalpy change. A fundamental knowledge should be mentioned that high entropy is beneficial for the structural stability because it is easy to make the Gibbs free energy lower than zero at a low temperature (ΔG = ΔH − TΔS). The more number of equimolar components for TMOs, the higher configurational entropy. Sarkar et al. synthesized 4-cationic HERO ((Co,Mg,Ni,Zn)O) with a single-phase rock-sat structure directly by nebulized spray pyrolysis (NSP) [62]. The synthesis temperature for (Co,Mg,Ni,Zn)O is higher than that of 5-cationic (Co,Cu,Mg,Ni,Zn)O, indicating the later has higher configurational entropy to be stabilized spontaneously. Then, Sarkar et al. further investigated the electrochemical performance of anodes for Li-ion batteries [9]. HERO (high entropy, 1.61 R) and MERO (middle entropy, 1.39 R) are denoted for the five and four mixed cations. The electrochemical performances show tremendous differences between the two systems. Briefly, HERO shows ∼ 420 mAh g−1 at the current density of 200 mA g−1 with the potential window of 0.01 to 3 V. The electrode exhibits increased capacity up to 600 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles (Fig. 3(b)). For the low current density of 50 mA g−1, HERO displays stable capacity from initial 555 to 520 mAh g−1 after 50 cycles, corresponding to the capacity retention of 93.7%. While MEROs show deteriorative performance. MERO-Zn (removing Zn from HERO) and MERO-Cu deliver the same initial capacity of 700 mAh g−1, however, the capacity retentions are only 31.4% and 57.1% after 50 cycles, respectively. Moreover, MERO-Co presents the worst initial capacity (∼450 mAh g−1) and the shortest lifespan (dead only after 10 cycles in Fig. 3(c)). It is noted that MERO-Cu demonstrates the lowest discharge potential, which is a suitable candidate for primary batteries (Fig. 3(d)). The better cycling performance of HERO is ascribed to its high configurational entropy, promoting the material to the initial rock-salt structure after lithiation, which is different from the traditional conversion reaction. During the discharge process, nanoscale Li2O and TM nuclei are generated through conversion reactions. However, the rock-salt structure is reserved at the end of discharge due to the trapped nano-particles in the rock-salt host matrix. As a result, X-ray diffraction (XRD) shows no typical peaks and the lithiated HERO is full of defects, which contributes to the diffusion of Li atoms and recovery of the structure to the original state in subsequent oxidation process. By contrast, MERO has no sufficient entropy to ensure the stability and full transformation. Thus, the advantages of high-entropy type compounds are presented in the electrochemical reaction. In situ chemical reactions during energy storage play an important role in revealing the mechanism and assisting with improved performance in the future. Hereafter, Ghigna et al. and Tavani et al. studied the lithiation mechanism of (Co,Cu,Mg,Ni,Zn)O further by operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) analysis [63,64]. They proposed different opinions that the conversion is irreversible and incomplete, even accompanied with alloy reaction, resulting in the collapsed compound structure. Results show that Cu2+ is the first species to be reduced when the potential is below 1.0 V, followed by Ni2+, and Co2+. It is noted that they also found the metallic Zn and Mg and their further alloying reaction with Li (while MgO is electrochemically inactive in related papers [9,45]). The different synthesis method is speculated on creating the divergence of the mechanisms. Actually, Ghigna and Tavani applied calcination treatment to obtain HERO, by which the particles are micro-sized, resulting in poor electrochemical performance. The lithium storage performance of Co-Cu-Mg-Ni-Zn-O has direct relationship with the synthesis method. Niu et al. used ball milling and calcination to make the nano-HERO [45]. This anode material maintains the reversible capacity of 920 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles with a potential window of 0.01–3 V under the current density of 100 mA g−1, which surpasses traditional Co3O4 distinctly. Even with the high current density of 3 A g−1, the electrode exhibits the discharge capacity of 490 mAh g−1. Then Niu also explored the effect of milling time on the battery performance [46]. A high pseudocapacitive contribution of 90.2% is calculated for the lithium storage in HERO. However, even expanding the milling time to 72 h, the electrochemical performance is not improved obviously. Kheradmandfard et al. used green microwave-assisted synthesis to obtain nano-HERO ultra-rapidly (3 min) [65]. The electrode shows the discharge capacity of 320 mAh g−1 at the current density of 1000 mA g−1 ranging from 0.01 to 3 V and holds a high capacity of over 98% after 1000 cycles. To explore the practical application of (Co,Cu,Mg,Ni,Zn)O, Wang et al. tested the full cell based on HERO as anode and LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2 as cathode [14]. The full cell shows an initial discharge capacity of 446 mAh g−1 and maintains 256 mAh g−1 for 100 cycles at the current density of 120 mA g−1 with a potential window of 0.5–4.5 V. 3.1.2 Derived AO type It is a usual method to modify the AO type composites by doping monovalent alkali ions, especially using Li-ions. Noting that all the TMs are of divalent in the typical HERO (Co,Cu,Mg,Ni,Zn)O. Herein, the dopant monovalent alkali-ion (Li+ for example) would change the charge compensation. Basically, there are two possible mechanisms. One is the oxidation of TMs (like Co2+ to Co3+), leading to the formula (Co,Cu,Mg,Ni,Zn)1- x Li x O [66]. Surprisingly, only Co has been oxidized for the charge compensation, evidenced by Anik et al. using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) [67]. For this case, the composite can be considered as doping Li2O, with the chemical composition (Cu0.2Mg0.2Ni0.2Zn0.2)O0.8⋅(0.2-2x)CoO⋅(x/2)(Co2O3⋅Li2O). The other strategy is the formation of oxygen vacancies, which is benefited from the Li-ions diffusion, corresponding to the formation of (Co0.2Cu0.2Mg0.2Ni0.2Zn0.2)1- x Li x O1- δ . Actually, the both mechanisms are found in the common Li-doped HEROs. Anik’s group investigated the electrochemical performance of (Mg,Co,Ni,Zn)1- x Li x O as anode for Li-ion batteries, with x ranging from 0.05 to 0.35 [67]. Here Mg2+ is not electrochemically active, and just stabilizes the stability of HERO through pillar effect [68]. The discharge capacity and cycling stability is a function of oxygen vacancies. The proposal of these modifications is derived from those the more Li content/oxygen vacancies would result in the higher capacities. Specifically, the HERO has the initial discharge capacity of 935, 1400, 1605, and 1930 mAh g−1 for 5%, 15%, 25%, and 35% Li dopant, respectively (Fig. 3(e)). For 35% Li-doped HERO, the anode maintains 610 mAh g−1 after 130 cycles at 1 A g−1 (Fig. 3(f)). Another typical derived composite is LiF-doped HERO, with the common chemical formula (Co,Cu,Mg,Ni,Zn)1- x Li y O1- x F y (for instance) or a more visualized formation (1-x)(Co,Cu,Mg,Ni,Zn)O⋅yLiF. The method is also facile through ball milling with LiF and HERO by which the composite can be directly obtained [15]. Anion dopant further increases the configuration entropy, which can be calculated by a derived Boltzmann-entropy equation, making the entropy larger than the enthalpy and improving the structural stability. Wang et al. reported LiF-doped entropy stabilized (Co,Cu,Mg,Ni,Zn)O⋅xLiF as a positive electrode of Li-ion batteries [15], which will be discussed in the following section. Hereafter, Breitung et al. further investigated the gassing behavior of (Co,Cu,Mg,Ni,Zn)O and Li(Co,Cu,Mg,Ni,Zn)OF in Li-ion batteries by differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) coupled with Infrared spectroscopy (IR) [69]. For HERO case, the anode shows the discharge capacity of ∼ 460 mAh g−1 at the current density of 200 mA g−1 after activation with the potential window of 0.01–2.5 V. Moreover, the anode delivers 300 mAh g−1 after 600 cycles with a capacity retention (65.2%). C2H4 and H2 are the most prominent gases during the discharge process when ethylene carbonate and fluoroethylene carbonate-based electrolyte are used. It is noted that these two gases exhibit maximum in the first discharge cycle, with the starting point when the potential falls down to 0.37 V. After the first cycle, the evolution rate of both gases decreases but not disappears, with the starting point of 0.18 V meanwhile. For LiF-HERO case, the sample as cathode shows 117 mAh g−1 at the current density of 20 mA g−1 with the potential window of 2.0–4.6 V. After 30 cycles, the cathode maintains 87 mAh g−1, corresponding to 74.4% retention. In this case, H2 also dominates the charged gaseous products, as well as CO2, companied by the limited O2, CO, and POF3. H2 and POF3 may be triggered by the generated protic species, and O2 comes from the lattice oxygen in HERO, which is a common phenomenon in Li-rich materials at high potential [70,71]. 3.1.3 A3O4 type The high entropy spinel oxides (HESO) with A3O4 type formula are considered to have 3D channels, providing higher Li-ion diffusion than the AO type HERO. Dabrowa et al. firstly synthesized the single phase HESO (Co,Cr,Fe,Mn,Ni)3O4 with Fd-3 m space group, in contrast with the Fm-3 m and R-3 m space groups in AO type HERO [12]. However, the electrochemical performance was not tested. It is noted that Rost pre-synthesized the composite while not obtained the single phase [72]. Wang et al. and Nguyen et al. further researched the electrochemical performance of (Co,Cr,Fe,Mn,Ni)3O4 [73,74]. Wang et al. obtained the single phase HESO (Fig. 4 (a)) and explored the effect of the calcined temperature on the lithium storage performance. HESOs obtained at 900 and 1000 °C show best rate capability and cycling stability at high current density, i.e., 600 and 402 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles at the current density of 500 mA g−1), respectively. The valences of TMs were also revealed by XPS results. Fe, Co, and Ni are of mixed bivalence and trivalence. Mn exhibits mixed trivalence and quadrivalence, while only Cr shows full trivalence. Moreover, rich oxygen vacancies were also detected which facilitate the transport of electron. It is noted that amorphous structure was formed and maintained during cycling (Fig. 4(b)), which creates rich defect in HESO, promoting Li-ion diffusion and restricting the volume changes. In Nguyen’s report, the HESO was synthesized by a surfactant-assisted hydrothermal method. The anode delivers a high capacity at the current density of 500 mA g−1, and keeps 90% capacity retention after 200 cycles. The superior performance is also benefited from the entropic stabilization and defect-rich oxygen vacancies. It is worth noting that the charge compensation in HESO shows discrepancy. For Nguyen’s case, Cr shows mixed trivalence and hexavalence rather than the single trivalence, and Mn displays three-mixed valences of + 2, +3, and + 4. The authors gave the detailed ratio of elements in various states, including the ratio of OL/OV/OC (L, V, C represent lattice, vacancies, and chemisorption, respectively). Remarkably, XPS is usually a surface-sensitive tool, gathering the information of several nanometers which may be the reason resulting in the discrepancy [75]. Beyond (Co,Cr,Fe,Mn,Ni)3O4, Chen et al. designed a new HESO of (Mg,Ti,Zn,Cu,Fe)3O4 with fast reaction kinetics [57]. In this case, inactive Mg2+ helps to stabilize the structure. Ti, Zn, Cu, and Fe are of single +4, +2, +2, and +3 valence, respectively. There are oxygen vacancies for the charge compensation. The anode delivers 634 and 290 mAh g−1 at the current density of 100 and 2000 mA g−1 in the initial cycles, respectively. For the capacity retention, 79.5% and 96.2% are achieved at the corresponded current density after 300 and 800 cycles, respectively. Other HESOs are also studied in the following year. Wang et al. investigated the charge compensation and structure evolution of three Li-incorporated HESOs, namely (Ni,Fe,Mn,Cr,Co) x O y (HESO–1), (Ni,Fe,Mn,Cr,Mg) x O y (HESO–2), and (Ni,Fe,Mn,Zn,Mg) x O y (HESO–3) [58]. XRD and inductive coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP) results demonstrate that the rock-salt phase appears if z > 0.6 for HESO–1 (Li z (Ni,Fe,Mn,Cr,Co) x O y ). When replacing Co2+/3+ by Mg2+ (HESO–2 case), the value of z decreases to 0.4. For HESO–3 case (Zn2+ substituting Cr3+/6+), the rock-salt transformation is complete when z > 0.4. The findings indicate that the lower average valence of TMs, the easier of rock-salt transformation in low Li concentrations. The Li content can tailor the structural composition, making the electrochemical performance controllable. 3.1.4 ABO3 and AO2 type ABO3 with typical perovskite structures are widely used in solar and fuel cells because their excellent physical properties. However, there are few reports about its application in Li-ion batteries, especially for high entropy perovskite oxides (HEPOs). Actually, Jiang et al., Sarkar et al., and Dabrowa et al. successfully synthesized homogeneous single phase HEPOs via calcination at high temperature [51,52,76]. Jiang et al. first tried (Sr, Ba) (occupying A site), and (Zr, Sn, Ti, Hf, Y, Nb, Ce) (occupying B site) for the single HEPO. Among 13 combined composites, only six have no mixed phase. All the HEPOs were obtained with the temperature higher than 1300 °C. Sarkar et al. further investigated 10-cationic HEPO, with (Gd, La, Nd, Sm, Y) and (Co, Cr, Fe, Mn, Ni) occupying A and B site, respectively. Dabrowa et al. designed 7-cationic HEPO, using (La, Sr) (A site) and (Co, Cr, Fe, Mn, Ni) (B site) with oxygen vacancies. This HEPO shows a high conductivity of over 16 S cm−1. These researches have laid a foundation for the subsequent application in lithium ion battery. Recently, Yan et al. proposed a 9-cationic HEPO, with (Bi,Na)(La,Li)(Ce,K)Ca,Sr occupying A site and Ti seizing B site (Fig. 4(c)) [50]. The coupled mono- and tri-valent element is for the charge balance. The sample as anode undergoes typical conversion reaction, delivering 125.9 mAh g−1 in initial cycle and holding at 120.4 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles at the current density of 1 A g−1 with the potential window from 0.01 to 3 V (Fig. 4(d)). Compared with foregoing HERO and HESO, HEPO shows inferior specific capacity. Actually, ABO3 type has more inactive oxygen than AO and A3O4 type (the atom rations of oxygen/metal are 1.5, 1, and 0.75, respectively). Moreover, there are electrochemically inactive TMs in HEPO (Bi, La, Sr for examples), releasing less electronic transformation and leading to low specific capacity. Similar situation can be found in non-HEPO La0.5Li0.5TiO3 [77]. Consequently, reasonable design of perovskite type HEMs can achieve ideal properties for batteries, rather than the maximization of configuration entropy. Accordingly, it is also suitable for the case of AO2 type. High entropy fluorite oxides (HEFOs) with AO2 type are mostly reported focusing on the TM series of (Ce, La, Pr, Sm, Y, Zr, Hf, Sn, Ti, Ho, Er, Yb) sometimes with oxygen vacancies [44,54,56]. There are rare reports about its application in Li-batteries, even though they show animation in fields of catalyst and thermal batteries [78,79]. This kind of HEOs is still waiting to be explored in the future. In order to figure out pros and cons of different HEMs anodes, we summarize the merits and challenges of various categories, as shown in Table1 . Considering that there is no corresponding report about AO2 type as anode of Li-ion batteries, this type is not involved here. From a point of scalability for various structures, AO type HEOs exhibit the greatest possibility. Spinel type one has better ionic conductivity and rate performance, while perovskite-type HEOs may not produce satisfactory capacity as the above two HEOs. 3.2 HEMs as cathodes Majority of HEOs are used for Li-ion batteries as anodes, as mentioned above. Generally, lithium should be incorporated into HEOs if the oxides act as positive electrode. The direct way for this target is to integrate lithium compounds. Li2O and LiF are the two common choices. For Li2O case, the valence of TMs would increase and/or the oxygen vacancies are produced to balance the charge when Li2O-incorporated HEOs are homogeneous single phase. In comparison, it is easier to incorporate LiF into HEOs than Li2O without disturbing the original HEOs because the ratio of cation/anion for LiF is equal to that of HEOs (considering AO type). Wang et al. applied Li2O as a dopant, obtaining a series of layered HEROs, Li(M1…M n )O2, where M can be Ni, Co, Mn, Al, Fe, Zn, Cr, Ti, Zr, and Cu. The oxides are confirmed to be single phase, however, the specific capacities are relatively low [32]. Breitung et al. integrated LiF into typical (Co,Cu,Mg,Ni,Zn)O, obtaining pure Li(Co,Cu,Mg,Ni,Zn)OF or (Co,Cu,Mg,Ni,Zn)O⋅LiF [69]. The cathode delivers the initial capacity of 117 mAh g−1, and maintains ∼ 87 mAh g−1 after 30 cycles at the current density of 20 mA g−1 in the voltage of 2.0–4.6 V. Actually, Wang et al. reported the same HEO⋅LiF earlier in 2019 with the similar method [15]. The authors investigated the structural evolution of the cathode for the initial cycle (Fig. 5 (a)). The cathode maintains the single rock-salt structure during de/lithiation process, only with slight shift of XRD peaks due to the changes of TM radius. During the charge process, Co, Cu, and Ni are electrochemically active while Mg and Zn are not. It is noted that the discharge capacity of the cathode is about 120 mAh g−1 for initial cycles under the current density of 20 mA g−1 from 2.0 to 4.5 V, which suffers obvious decay while recovers back to the original value after 300 cycles (Fig. 5(b)). Subsequently, Lun et al. synthesized 6-cationic HERO utilizing LiF and Li2O co-incorporation [47], namely L i 1.3 M n 0.1 2 + C o 0.1 2 + M n 0.1 3 + C r 0.1 3 + T i 0.1 N b 0.2 O 1.7 F 0.3 (TM6), based on L i 1.3 M n 0.4 3 + T i 0.3 O 1.7 F 0.3 and L i 1.3 M n 0.2 2 + M n 0.2 3 + T i 0.1 N b 0.2 O 1.7 F 0.3 as reference (TM2 and TM4). All the samples show perfect rock-salt structure with Fm-3 m space group without impurity, evidenced by XRD and energy dispersive spectrum (EDS) mapping. Moreover, with TM species increasing from 2 to 6, the cation short-range order (SRO) is suppressed effectively, which can be observed from the intensity of the diffuse scattering pattern (Fig. 5(c)). Suppressed SRO is commonly considered to be beneficial for the Li diffusion. In view of that cation-disordered rock-salt materials usually display poor Li-diffusion, the restricted SRO and high Li content (>1, triggering 0-TM percolation [80]) shows remarkable impact. As exhibited in Fig. 5(d), the discharge capacities are increased with TMs number (220, 269, and 307 mAh g−1 at the current density of 20 mA g−1 between 1.5 to 4.7 V for TM2, TM4, and TM6, corresponding to 704, 849, and 955 Wh kg−1, respectively). Particularly, the rate performances are improved significantly thanks to the limited SRO (capacity loss of 74%, 58%, and 45% for TM2, TM4, and TM6 when the current density is changed from 20 mA g−1 to 2000 mA g−1). For redox mechanism, Cr, Mn, Co, and O are in charge of electrochemically active, providing reversible capacity. There is no such difference of the redox behavior among three materials. Moreover, the authors further successfully obtained HERO with 12 TM species (TM12, Fig. 5(e)), which is the maximum-species included in HEOs with disorder-arranged cations as far as we search the literatures. The electrochemical performance of TM12 was also tested, however, it is not superior compared with TM6. Actually, with the increase of TM species, the reduced SRO improves Li transport on one hand. The electrochemically active TMs are diluted on the other hand, resulting in relatively low performance. Therefore, it is a trade-off between high entropy and impressed electrochemical performance. In contrast to the application of HEOs in lithium ion batteries, there are relatively few reports about their application in Na-ion batteries. Inspired by the successful experiences in energy storage system, Zhao et al. designed a 9-cationic HEO, which is of typical layered O3 structure (R-3 m space group, Fig. 6 (a)), namely NaNi0.12Cu0.12Mg0.12Fe0.15Co0.15Mn0.1Ti0.1Sn0.1Sb0.04O2 with typical charge–discharge curve shown in Fig. 6(c) [10]. Here Ni2+, Cu2+, Fe3+ and Co3+ are redox active; Mg2+ and Ti4+ are electrochemically inactive for stabilizing the structural framework; Mn4+ supports the whole pristine structure; Sn4+ and Sb5+ raise the average voltage. The electrode displays fast Na-ion diffusion kinetics and low polarization. At the high current density of 360 mA g−1, the cathode maintains 83% capacity retention after 500 cycles with the potential window of 2.0–3.9 V (Fig. 6(d)), which is markedly superior to the general O3 type cathodes [81–83]. The O3 HEO also exhibits the typical O3–P3 phase transition. However, O3 region holds more than 60% of the total capacity due to the high entropy properties, which promotes good reversibility and cycling stability. Yang et al. proposed another typical layered Na-deficient HEO with 5 TM species and P2 structure (P63/mmc space group), Na0.6(Ti0.2Mn0.2Co0.2Ni0.2Ru0.2)O2 (Fig. 6(b)) [84]. Benefited from high entropic stability (uniformed distribution of TMs), the ordering of Na+/vacancy is suppressed and the fast Na-ion diffusion channel with percolating low-barrier is created. The cathode shows significant rate performance (68 mAh g−1 at the current density of 15000 mA g−1, Fig. 6(e)). It is noted that the capacity over 4 V in the first cycle suffers irreversibility in the following cycles, suggesting the anionic redox. If the upper voltage is confined from 4.5 V to 4.2 V, the cathode would exhibit improved long cycling stability (Fig. 6(f)). 3.3 HEO as solid-state electrolyte (SSE) There are many researches focusing on the solid-state electrolytes because of their safety. They are considered as the best replacements of the traditional liquid electrolyte. A satisfying SSE must have high ionic conductivity and low electrical conductivity. Berardan et al. investigated the ionic and electronic conductivity in a popular HEO (Co,Cu,Mg,Ni,Zn)O and A x Ga y (A = Li, Na, K) doped compounds [85]. Meanwhile, the charge compensation of the materials after substituting A x Ga y was revealed. XPS was used to confirm the formation of Co3+ and/or oxygen vacancies when introducing Li+, Na+, and K+. The ionic conductivity of the HEOs has direct relationship with the concentration of alkali-ions (σ i = 10−3, 6 × 10−6, and 8 × 10−9 S cm−1 for 33% Li, 15% Na, and 5% K at 20 °C, respectively). However, the effect of Li x Ga y co-doping on oxygen vacancies is very limited because Li and Ga3+ are responsible for the charge compensation. Indeed, when improving the content Li and Ga, the σ i of the HEOs actually decreases (from 3 × 10−8 with Li0.025Ga0.025 to 2 × 10−10 with Li0.05Ga0.05, for one example). Hereafter, the electronic conductivity of the HEOs was evaluated from the evolution of the current density when applying 1 V step on the blocking electrodes. Both HEO and Li-substituted HEO show similar behavior, indicating there is no effect of Li doping on the electronic conductivity (σ e). In their cases, the σ e is estimated as 2 × 10−9 S cm−1, indicating electronic insulator property. Herein, the Li-substituted HEO can be a choice of SSE. The monovalent Li induces oxygen vacancies for charge compensation, promoting Li-HEO a high ionic conductivity at room temperature which is more than 2 orders larger than that of lithium phosphorous oxy-nitride (LiPON). Afterwards, Osenciat et al. investigated the influence of Li-substituted HEO on Li superionic conductivity [66]. Oxygen deficiencies induced by introduced Li act as the key factor for the enhanced ionic conductivity. Specifically, the ionic conductivity exceeds 1 mS cm−1 at room temperature when doping 21% Li in HEO. However, the Li+ mobility is hampered with more oxygen vacancies. The mechanism of ionic conductivity for HEO should be a further research topic. Very recently, however, Mozdzierz et al. proposed that Li-substituted (Co,Cu,Mg,Ni,Zn)O has mixed ionic-electronic property [86]. Different with the technique used by Berardan et al., Mozdzierz applied impedance spectroscopy (EIS) to detect the electronic transport of Li-HEO. Two parallel resistances correspond ionic R i and electronic R e, respectively. They observed increased electronic property of Li-HEO with increased dopant Li. Especially, the σ e changes from no more than 10−8 S cm−1 for HEO to 10−3 level for 30% Li-substituted HEO. Moreover, they used the Li-HEO as SSE for Li|LiCoO2 cell and found there was no open circuit voltage, demonstrating the electronic property of the Li-HEO. From the aspect of application, the Li-HEOs has no successful case for battery as SSE. However, the new family compounds provide us more possibilities to modify and design the suitable SSE. 3.4 Outlook of HEMs in field of battery In this part, we have reviewed the applications of HEMs in the batteries, as anode, cathode, and solid-state electrolyte. These type HEMs in the field of batteries have grown rapidly in recent years, and exhibit continuous and booming vitality, such as the catalysts and chemical anchor of polysulfides in lithium-sulfur batteries [87,88] and sodium-ion battery [89]. However, the oxides are still in the infancy compared with the traditional materials for Li-ion batteries. Here, a brief summary and outlook is shown as followed. To compare these materials conveniently, the electrochemical performances of the above-mentioned typical HEOs as anode and cathode are displayed in Table 2 and Table 3 , respectively. For the anodes, the majority of HEOs are of AO type rock-salt structure, which are commonly classified by Fm-3 m and R-3 m space groups. The HEOs show superior electrochemical performance due to the entropic stabilization. Especially, in contrast to the conventional conversion reaction, HEOs display the high reversibility with TMs nuclei incorporated into the well-maintained rock-salt host matrix. It is noted that the particle size is the key factor on the redox mechanism. LiF and Li2O are the two common composites incorporating into HEOs to enhance the ionic and/or electronic conductivity. With the increasing atom proportion of oxygen (from AO to A3O4, ABO3 etc.), the delivered capacity of HEOs decreases. In terms of batteries, HEPOs and HOFOs are rarely proposed because high-valence TMs are needed in these type HEOs, which usually are not electrochemically active. As one good anode, high capacity and low average outputted potential are required. Herein, AO type HEOs seem to be optimal. In addition, other elements (Fe, Ti, and Mn for instance) can be considered to be incorporated because most of the current AO type HEOs are focused on the 5-cationic (Co,Cu,Mg,Ni,Zn)O. There might be the most favorable combination of HEOs (the number and category of metal-ions) for the highly stable capacity and long cycling performance. For the design of HEO cathodes, it is not simply the higher entropy (TM species), the better electrochemical performance because more mixed TMs mean scarce redox-active TMs. There is a trade-off depending on your choice: high energy or high entropy. For the selectable elements, Mn2+, V3+, and Mo4+ can be chosen as redox centers due to their two or three electrons transfer. Fe2+, Co2+ and Ni2+ are usually considered as one-electron redox centers because of their overlapping orbits with oxygen in the oxidized states. Mg2+, Ti4+, and Nb5+ are electrochemically inactive and can be used as stabilizers. Sn4+ and Sb5+ could be applied for raising the average voltage, as well as the redox-active Cr3+. The suppressed SRO contributes to Li-diffusion and promotes high rate performance. However, the particle sizes are also the key point to affect the rate capability due to the high activity of nano-particles with the electrolyte, indicating parasitic reaction and capacity loss. The current researches mainly include AO type materials (rock-salt structures with Fm-3 m or R-3 m space group), other types such as spinel (A3O4 with three dimensional diffusion channels) and perovskite (ABO3 with excellent physical properties) can be considered. 4 Application of HEMs in electrochemical supercapacitors Electrochemical supercapacitors as another promising high-power energy storage devices are paid much attention due to their advantages of ultrafast energy transfer, virtually unlimited cycle life, and ultrahigh power density [90]. Different from traditional carbon materials [91,92] based on the double-layer capacitance mechanism, metal oxide and other compounds, such as NiO [93], Co3O4 [94], Fe2O3 [95,96], TiO2 [97], and Nb4N5 [98], can store more energy based on the faradaic reaction mechanism. The theoretical capacity and potential window of unitary metal compounds in practical use are limited due to their relatively fixed redox potential. Consequently, the development of multi-metallic compounds with multiple redox pairs may expand the energy storage potential window and capacity. In addition, multicomponent compounds equip higher electrochemical activity and larger electronic conductivity based on previous research, which are at least two orders of magnitude higher than traditional compounds [99]. The unique electrochemical property of HEMs endows them the potential to be novel energy storage materials. However, the relevant work are waiting to be developed in recent years. Therefore, the entropy-driven strategy has broad application prospects in the field of supercapacitors. Recently, there have been some reports on HECs for supercapacitor applications, such as high-entropy oxides and nitrides [100]. Because they exhibit relatively comprehensible structure on the basis of unitary oxides and reveal similar energy storage mechanism. For example, Kong et al. [26] fabricated a core/shell structure with the inner core of nanoporous metal and shell of oxide using FeNiCoCrAl HEA precursor by selective phase dissolution (Fig. 7 (a)). By selectively dissolving the Al–Ni-rich phase, the resultant nanoporous HEM demonstrates high capacitance (700F cm−3) and superior cycling stability (3000 cycles) with the binder-free electrode (Fig. 5(b–d)). With the refinement of the nanoporous microstructure, this HEM affords better performance than those of materials reported so far. Jin et al. reported a high-entropy nitride of (CrMoNbVZr)N with a cubic crystal structure by mechanochemical-assisted soft urea method, as shown in Fig. 7(e) [20]. This resultant nitride displays its potential as supercapacitor materials with high specific capacitances from 230 to 54F g−1 at 10 to 200 mV s−1 in 1 M KOH (Fig. 7(g)). The capacitance for (CrMoNbVZr)N at 100 mV s−1 is larger than that of VN@C nanowires, revealing the possibility for utilization of HEMs in supercapacitors [101]. These two work are the attempt to apply HEMs in supercapacitor, and they don’t intensively study the effect of high entropy on capacity and stability. Apart from the active materials, appropriate substrates can provide a faster conductive path and optimize the dispersion of active materials, so as to improve the electrochemical stability of energy storage materials. Aligned carbon nanofibers (ACNFs) are beneficial for the synthesis of uniform films, and the thickness of the oxides layer can be tuned with adjusting the deposition current and time [102]. For example, Xu et al. [27] reported FeNiCoMnMg HEA nanoparticles on ACNFs by the carbothermal shock (CTS) method (Fig. 8 (a)). The electrodes of FeNiCoMnMg/CNF have excellent performance for energy storage with a high specific capacitance of 203F g−1, high energy density of 21.7 Wh kg−1, and long durability of 2000 cycles (Fig. 8(b–c)). These results display that the HEA NPs/carbonaceous composite materials possess potential for supercapacitors. Moreover, Lal et al. [103] synthesized FeNiCoCrAl-based HEO NPs using a sol–gel auto combustion method and loaded them on carbon nanotubes. The nanocomposite delivers a specific capacitance of 271F g−1 at 1 A g−1 in ionic liquid (Fig. 8(d–e)). And it exhibits a specific capacitance of 71 F g−1 at the current density of 1 A g−1 in PVA/H2SO4 electrolyte with stable capacity up to 15 k cycles (Fig. 8(f–h)). Therefore, polymetallic materials based on the high-entropy effect and their further improvement with conductive substrates show great application potential in the supercapacitor area. 5 Summary and prospect In this review, the latest advances of HEMs applied in electrochemical energy storage are summarized. Recently, the effort of incorporating multiple cations or anions to increase the configurational entropy opens up new areas for designing energy storage materials. In these chemical complex systems, the phase stabilization effect by the entropy controlling strategy is conducive to the improved performance of the materials. For example, this strategy contributes for the reversible lithiation/delithiation behavior. In the future, the combination of high capacity and stable cycling endows the possibility for HEMs in solid-state batteries. Although HEMs have all potential advantages over traditional compounds, there are still many obvious challenges in their practical applications. The following statements will focus on the existing problems and possible improvements for HEMs. (1) The exploration of new classes of HEMs is an attractive direction in the future. Traditional HEM mainly are paid attention to the common compound, specifically multi-metallic compounds. However, HEMs family is also extended to the polyanion and polycation systems, such as heteropolyacid (HPA) and polyoxometalates (POMs). HPA and POMs equip a variety of crystalline structures (Keggin, Dawson, Anderson, Sinverton, Strandberg, and Lindgvist structure). The most familiar Keggin structure consists of [XM12O40] n − (X = P, Si, Ge, As, etc., M = Mo, and W) and maybe have applications in the energy storage. In addition, an interesting attempt includes introducing the high-entropy concept into metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) [104,105] and layered double hydroxides (LDHs) [106], which can achieve large entropy at ambient temperature. There are just a few relevant works published so far, however, they provide sketch ideas of HEMs with unique morphology and nanoscale, as well as the fresh functional applications [107]. (2) The overall performances of HEMs for batteries are waiting to be enhanced for practical applications. The advantages of HEOs over conventional oxides for battery applications are still waiting to be explored, considering that the cycling performance of typical (CoMgCuNiZn)O as anode cannot meet the actual demands [9]. Fortunately, the rock-salt structure of pristine HEMs is partly retained during cycling, guaranteeing the entropy-stabilized conversion mechanism. Based on this mechanism, the relationship between the entropy-driven stability and the enhanced electrochemical performance would be revealed and it will enhance the performance of HEMs. Moreover, as for the application of cathodes, the high entropy strategy will facilitate the stability of O3-type structure and improve the capacity. Consequently, high entropy compounds are a class of promising candidate for batteries. (3) The research of HEMs applied in electrochemical supercapacitors is still in its infancy. Apart from studied polymetallic oxides, some unique carbides [18], sulfides [21], and nitrides [20] can also be considered as supercapacitor materials. These high-entropy compounds possess various crystalline structures and relatively open interior structure than HEOs, making larger specific surface area and better capacity. Moreover, the less studied early transition metal elements are also a field worth to be explored, such as TiO2, Nb2O5, and Ta2O5. In the future, combined with artificial intelligence, optimizing the composition and structure of materials in advance and reasonably predicting their properties can also be expanded. (4) Identifying functional units and understanding the structure–activity relationship between the composite and performance At present, the functional design of HEMs is still in the early stage, and the tailoring structure strategy has achieved the purpose of optimizing performance, which is in a random fashion. Thus, rationally designing high entropy materials and revealing the intrinsic structure–activity relationship is very challenging at present. In the computational approach, machine learning (ML) techniques enable the design of HEMs according to different desired demands. A certain structure–activity relationship for entropy-increasing effect and specific electrochemical properties, such as theoretical charge/discharge specific capacity, cycle stability and capacitor potential window, contribute to the long-term development in this field. Choosing a benchmark model and reasonably adding or substituting new elements is also an effective approach. By adding or replacing appropriate elements and observing the resulting performance changes, the role of some key elements in the energy storage process can be roughly obtained. Comprehensive utilization of experimental evidence, kinetics analysis, and density functional theory (DFT) calculations can reveal the specific structure–activity relationship. (5) Expanding more energy storage systems and application scenarios Based on the enormous family of HEMs, they have more application scenarios in the energy storage and electrochemical conversion. Apart from the electrochemical energy storage approach, other pathways are also feasible, such as phase change energy storage, superconducting energy storage, flow cell energy storage, and chemical conversion energy storage. Many HEMs are used as the advanced electrocatalysts [108,109] to transform redundant electric energy to hydrogen or syngas. Therefore, these materials will present a bright future in the field of energy and catalysis. Overall, the high entropy concept could possibly pave the way to develop advanced materials. Despite the above challenges, the research progress has been satisfactory, and there are many opportunities in other energy fields for HEMs, such as comprehensive utilization of carbon dioxide. It is believed that HEMs as newly developed materials would lead the new trend of energy reform. Jiang, Tungsten 3 (2021) 161–180. Xin Wang received his Ph.D. degree at Peking University in 2018 under the supervision of Prof. Fuqiang Huang. In 2018, he joined the College of Chemistry at Zhengzhou University in China as a lecture. His current research is focused on the the rational design and synthesis alloy-based high-entropy materials with the exploring of electrocatalytic properties. Xiang Li is a Lecturer in the College of Chemistry at Zhengzhou University in China. He obtained his Ph.D. at University of Tsukuba (Japan) in 2019. His research is focused on electrochemical energy storage, including positive electrode materials for Li/Na-ion batteries and Li metal anode. Yongzhu Fu is Professor in the College of Chemistry at Zhengzhou University in China. He received his Ph.D. degree in Materials Science and Engineering from the University of Texas at Austin (USA) in 2007. He was an Assistant Professor at Indiana University-Purdue University, Indianapolis, in the United States before he joined Zhengzhou University in 2017. His research is focused on electrochemical energy materials.

coredata.dc:description: Recently, high-entropy materials (HEMs) have gained increasing interest in the field of energy storage technology on account of their unique structural characteristics and possibilities for tailoring functional properties. Herein, the development of this class of materials for electrochemical energy storage have been reviewed, especially the fundamental understanding of entropy-dominated phase-stabilization effects and prospective applications are presented. Subsequently, critical comments of HEMs on the different aspects of battery and supercapacitor are summarized with the underlying principles for the observed properties. In addition, we also summarize their potential advantages and remaining challenges, which will ideally provide some general guidelines and principles for researchers to study and develop advanced HEMs. The diversity of material design contributed by the entropy-mediated concept provides the researchers numerous ideas of new candidates for practical applications and ensures further research in the emerging field of energy storage.
